Dear Mack McGhee:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was admitted to the facility and has not been provided her
medication since admission due to the staff not having time. Youth
has serious mental health issues and requires medication.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was contacted on 09/24/2024 by email and notified
that an investigation is underway based on the allegation
received. Complainant has not reached out by phone or email with
additional information.
Youth A’s mother was interviewed on 09/06/2024 by phone.
Youth A’s mother stated Youth A was placed at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention Facility on 09/03/2024 and has not received
her medications as of 09/06/2024.Youth A’s mother is concerned
that Youth A will experience auditory hallucinations without her
medications. I spoke with Youth A’s mother on 10/28/2024 by
phone. Youth A’s mother stated Youth A was discharged to her on
10/05/2024 with the three medications as prescribed by the
psychiatrist at Wayne County Juvenile Detention Facility. I spoke
with Youth A’s mother on 10/31/2024 by phone. Youth A’s mother
stated Youth A’s medications were sent with her at the time of
placement on 09/03/2024 in the original medication bottle with the
name of prescribing doctor and telephone number and the name
of the pharmacy.
Youth A was interviewed on 09/11/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention Facility with another Department of Health and
Human Service (DHHS) worker. Youth A stated she met with
Psychiatrist on 09/09/2024 and started her medications. I
interviewed Youth A again on 09/23/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention Facility. Youth A was neatly dressed in issued
clothing with appropriate footwear. Youth A stated she continues
to receive her medications without issue.
2

Psychiatrist was interviewed on 09/23/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention Facility with another DHHS worker. Psychiatrist
stated a newly admitted female youth must take a pregnancy test
and have signed medication consent forms prior to him
prescribing and the youth taking medication. Psychiatrist stated
this process typically takes up to 7-days to complete from the date
of admission. Psychiatrist stated he had Youth A’s mother review
and sign for four medications that Youth A took prior to admission.
Psychiatrist stated after meeting with Youth A and reviewing her
medications, he prescribed three of the four medications.
Psychiatrist stated he spoke Youth A’s mother about Youth A’s
medications.
Division of Child Welfare Licensing Program Manager spoke
with DHHS Physician on 12/09/2024. The list below is from their
conversation about issues when a youth is admitted with
prescribed medication and does not immediately receive the
medication following admission.
• A youth may experience adverse response when
medication is not tapered or medication dispensing is
disrupted.
• A youth may be emotionally and medically at risk.
• A youth may experience diagnostic symptoms.
• A youth may experience withdrawal symptoms from the
medication.
DHHS Physician stated medications, such as, epi pens, asthma
inhalers, and seizure medications are to be available immediately.
Documentation
Youth A’s medical documentation
• 09/04/2024 Youth A’s initial assessment completed.
• Nursing contacted Youth A’s mother about Youth A’s
medications and forwarded information to Psychiatrist.
• 09/09/2024 Medication consent form with four medications
that Youth A was on prior to admission was signed by
Youth A’s mother.
• 09/09/2024 Youth A met with Psychiatrist. Psychiatrist
ordered three of the four medications that Youth A was on
prior to her admission.
• 09/26/2024 Psychiatrists’ note states Youth A is to continue
with the medications as he prescribed.
Youth A’s medication administration record shows Youth A started
taking her medications on 09/09/2024.
3

Wayne County Juvenile Detention policy and procedure 17.1
Health Screening and Health Assessment states that mental
health screening is done during initial intake assessment and a
urine pregnancy test is done during initial medication screening.
Wayne County Juvenile Detention policy and procedure 17.12
Use of Pharmaceuticals states youth arriving with medication may
have their medications continued with the approval of the
responsible doctor. The reason and duration of the treatment must
be documented in the youth’s chart by the doctor. It further states
the medication must be in the original medication bottle with the
name of the prescribing doctor and telephone number and the
name of the pharmacy for the medication to be verified.
Wayne County Juvenile Detention policy and procedure 17.12
Use of Pharmaceuticals specifically states Informed Consent form
must be obtained for each psychotropic medication ordered and
administered.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance in delaying the dispensing
of Youth A’s medication. Youth A was admitted on 09/03/2024 and
restarted her medications as prescribed by Wayne County
Juvenile Detention’s psychiatrist on 09/09/2024.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Medication consent forms are for prescribed medication. Another
medication consent form is needed if a medication is not
prescribed or discontinued or dosage changes.
DHHS physician provided the following suggestions:
• Policy should address the individual needs of a youth in
care.
• Wayne County Juvenile Detention is to utilize all resources
to gather medication information at the youth’s admission
(i.e. from workers, parents, etc.) They can also confirm
medication prescriptions with the pharmacy. Withholding
prescribed medication until seen by the agency physician is
not medically advised.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4

Rule Code Program statement.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to the admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth has also not been able to have phone contact with her
parent.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was contacted on 09/24/2024 by email and notified
that an investigation is underway based on the allegation
received. Complainant has not reached out by phone or email with
additional information.
Youth A’s mother was interviewed on 09/06/2024 by phone.
Youth A’s mother stated she spoke with Youth A on 09/06/2024
and does not have further concerns with phone calls.
Youth A was interviewed on 09/11/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention Facility with another Department of Health and
Human Service (DHHS) worker. Youth A stated she spoke to her
mother on the phone since her admission, but does not recall the
dates. I interviewed Youth A again on 09/23/2024. Youth A stated
there was recently an issue with her phone code and she was
unable to make a call to her mother this past week. Youth A stated
her case manager is aware of the issue and working to resolve it.
Manager was interviewed on 09/23/2024. Manager stated there
was an issue with youth pin codes to make authorized outside
calls. Manager stated this issue was fixed and youths are now
able to use their pin codes to make authorized outside calls.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with Youth A having phone
contact with her mother.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
5

As a result of the findings in this investigation, a corrective action plan is required.
